title: 2024 CSS wishlist
description: What I’ve love to see for CSS in 2024.
html:
2023 was a great year for CSS. Notably, we has :has() and we got nesting across browsers now! And there’s so much more.

In 2024, I’d love to see the following implemented in all browsers:

1. Style queries for custom properties

These are going to revolutionize how we write component styles. One significant use-case is allowing you to create your own custom-CSS-API for a component—I’ll write more on this in the future.

2. text-box-trim and margin-trim

These aren’t the same, but I’ve grouped them together because they are just so useful for typography. I recently created a printed document and I used Safari Technology Preview just so I could use both of these. They seem like low hanging fruit for implementation.

3. The @scope rule

So much of the styles we write are candidate for the CSS @scope rule. Miriam Suzanne has a fantastic article about this. Also, scope proximity is fascinating!

4. Scroll-driven animations

I work on websites that use scroll animations all over the place. Being able to do these all with CSS would be awesome and there are so many other use cases for them beyond just your typical scrolly-telling sites.

5. Types for attr()

Using attribute values for properties other than content would be great. This goes hand-in-hand with style queries and will greatly improve how we write component styles.

6. Anchor positioning

While I haven’t been following this too closely, the fact that there is work being done here is fantastic and makes me excited for its implementation across browsers. I’m elated to see all that we can now achieve without JS that is also accessible.

7. View transitions

View transitions are magical and I really do hope we see more progress here towards stable implementation.

Thank you CSS wish fulfillers

I want to end this by expressing gratitude for everyone involved in the process of making these CSS wishes come true. Whether you are working on specifications, research, implementation, experimenting, or offering feedback—I am so grateful for you and your work. You make the web a better place. Thank you!
